question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
John computes the sum of the elements of each of the 15 two-element subsets of $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$. What is the sum of these 15 sums?
inference:
The sum of the elements of the two-element subsets is
$$ \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} (i+j) = \sum_{i=1}^6 \sum_{j=i+1}^6 (i+j) = \sum_{i=1}^6 \sum_{j=i+1}^6 i + \sum_{i=1}^6 \sum_{j=i+1}^6 j = \sum_{i=1}^6 i \sum_{j=i+1}^6 1 + \sum_{j=2}^6 j \sum_{i=1}^{j-1} 1 = \sum_{i=1}^6 i (6-i) + \sum_{j=2}^6 j (j-1)$$
The first sum is
$$ \sum_{i=1}^6 i (6-i) = \sum_{i=1}^6 (6i - i^2) = 6 \sum_{i=1}^6 i - \sum_{i=1}^6 i^2 = 6 \frac{6(7)}{2} - \frac{6(7)(13)}{6} = 6(21) - 7(13) = 126 - 91 = 35 $$
The second sum is
$$ \sum_{j=2}^6 j(j-1) = \sum_{j=2}^6 (j^2 - j) = \left(\sum_{j=2}^6 j^2 \right) - \left(\sum_{j=2}^6 j \right) = \sum_{j=1}^6 j^2 - 1 - \sum_{j=1}^6 j + 1 = \frac{6(7)(13)}{6} - \frac{6(7)}{2} = 91 - 21 = 70 $$
The sum of all pairs is $35+70 = 105$.
The sum of all elements of these two-element subsets is
$$ \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} (i+j) = \sum_{i=1}^6 \sum_{j=i+1}^6 (i+j) = \sum_{i=1}^6 i(6-i) + \sum_{j=2}^6 j (j-1) = 105 $$
Each pair $(i,j), i<j$ appears twice. There are $\binom{6}{2} = \frac{6(5)}{2} = 15$ such pairs. The average of the elements of these pairs is $\frac{105}{15} = 7$.
Since there are 15 subsets of size 2, and each subset consists of two elements $i,j$, the sum is
$$\sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} (i+j) = 2\sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} \frac{i+j}{2}$$
Each pair $(i,j)$ appears twice, once as $(i,j)$ and once as $(j,i)$. Thus,
$$ \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} (i+j) = \frac{2\sum_{i=1}^6 i \sum_{j=1}^6 j - \sum_{i=1}^6 i^2}{2\sum_{j=1}^6 1} = \frac{2\sum_{i=1}^6 i \sum_{j=1}^6 j - \sum_{j=1}^6 i^2}{2 \binom{6}{2}} = 105 $$
Thus the sum of the sums is $105 \times 15 = 1575$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{1575}$
ground_truth: Among the two-element subsets of $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$, each element in $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$ appears 5 times, one time in the same subset with each other element. Thus, the desired sum is $5(1+2+3+4+5+6)=5\left(\frac{6\cdot7}{2}\right)=\boxed{105}$.

$$ \sum_{j=2}^6 j(j-1) = \sum_{j=2}^6 (j^2 - j) = \left(\sum_{j=2}^6 j^2 \right) - \left(\sum_{j=2}^6 j \right) = \sum_{j=1}^6 j^2 - 1 - \sum_{j=1}^6 j + 1 = \frac{6(7)(13)}{6} - \frac{6(7)}{2} = 91 - 21 = 70 $$

inference:
The sum of the elements of the two-element subsets is
$$\sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} (i+j) = 2 \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} i + 2 \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} j = 2 \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} i + 2 \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} j$$
$$ = 2 \sum_{i=1}^6 i \sum_{j=i+1}^6 1 = 2 \sum_{i=1}^6 i (6-i) = 2 (35) = 70 $$
The sum of all two-element subsets is
$$ \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} (i+j) = 2\sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} i + 2 \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} j = 2 \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} i + 2 \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} j = 2\left( \sum_{i=1}^6 \sum_{j=i+1}^6 i \right) + 2\left(\sum_{i=1}^6 \sum_{j=i+1}^6 j \right)$$
$$ = 2 \sum_{i=1}^6 i (6-i) + 2 \sum_{j=2}^6 j (j-1) = 2 \left( \sum_{i=1}^6 6i - i^2 \right) = 2(35 + 70) = 2 \times 105 = 210 $$
There are $\binom{6}{2} = 15$ subsets of size 2. The sum of the elements is $2( \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} i ) = 2 \times 105 = 210$.
The sum is $2\sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} i + 2 \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} j = 2\sum_{i=1}^6 i(6-i)/2 = 2(35) = 70$. 
We calculated the sum of the elements of the subsets. This is $ 2\sum_{i=1}^6 i \sum_{j=i+1}^6 1 + 2 \sum_{j=2}^6 j(j-1) = 2(35) + 2(70) = 105 \times 2 = 210 $

The total sum of the elements in these 15 subsets is 
$$2 \sum_{1\le i < j \le 6} i + 2 \sum_{1 \le i < j \le 6} j = 2\sum_{1\le i<j\le 6} (i+j) = 2\sum_{1\le i < j \le 6} i + 2 \sum_{1\le i<j\le 6} j$$
$$=2 \sum_{i=1}^6 i(6-i) = 2(105) = 210 $$

There are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ such subsets. The sum of the elements of these subsets is $15 \times 2 \times \frac{6 \times 7}{4} = 15 \times 21 = 315$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{210}$
ground_truth: Among the two-element subsets of $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$, each element in $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$ appears 5 times, one time in the same subset with each other element. Thus, the desired sum is $5(1+2+3+4+5+6)=5\left(\frac{6\cdot7}{2}\right)=\boxed{105}$.
